column15:
[club38614017||FIVE WAYS TO SPEAK ENGLISH MORE NATURALLY]

You are learning English. Of course you want to speak naturally
column16:
as if you were American or British. But how can you do this? Here are five tips to help.

1 - use ‚Äòget‚Äô

‚ÄòGet‚Äô is one of the most useful ‚Äì and most used ‚Äì words in the English language. English speakers use it all the time! Take a look at this example:
English Learner: What time did you arrive?
Native Speaker: What time did you get there?
‚ÄòGet‚Äô has so many meanings. It can mean ‚Äòtake‚Äô or ‚Äòbuy‚Äô. English learners often have trouble using ‚Äòget‚Äô to mean ‚Äòbecome‚Äô:
English Learner: I became angry when the train was late.
Native Speaker: I got angry when the train was late.
In fact
column17:
we generally use ‚Äòget‚Äô for temporary situations and ‚Äòbecome‚Äô for permanent situations.
Temporary: She got bored with the movie.
Permanent: Ralph became a doctor at age twenty-five.
Incorrect: Ralph got a doctor at age twenty-five.

2 - use ‚Äòused to‚Äô

‚ÄòUsed to‚Äô is one of the most useful phrases in English
column18:
and it is even easy to pronounce. English learners often get confused when they try to substitute a phrase from their own language:
English Learner: Last time
column19:
I smoked a lot.
English Learner: I smoked a lot
column21:
no.
Native Speaker: I used to smoke a lot.
Here‚Äôs a word of warning. There are two forms of ‚Äòused to‚Äô in English and they both have different meanings and grammatical structures:
Example 1: I used to be a policeman.
Example 2: I am used to eating spicy food.
In example 1
column24:
the meaning is ‚Äòfamiliar with‚Äô.

3 - use ‚Äòmanaged to‚Äô

Here is another phrase that does not translate easily into other languages. As a result
column25: it is difficult for learners to start using. To manage to do something is to succeed in doing it. However
column26: if you use the phrase ‚Äòsucceed‚Äô instead
column27:
the result sounds clumsy:
English Learner: Did you succeed to find the keys that you lost?
Native Speaker: Did you manage to find the keys that you lost?

4 - use ‚Äòabout to‚Äô

‚ÄòAbout to‚Äô is a little phrase that is surprisingly useful. Listen out for it and you will be surprised how often you hear it used. We use this phrase to show that something will happen soon. Here is how a native speaker might use it:
English Learner: I think it is going to rain soon.
Native Speaker: It looks like it‚Äôs about to rain.
English Learner: I can‚Äôt have another coffee. I am going soon.
Native Speaker: I don‚Äôt have time for another coffee. I‚Äôm about to go.

5 - don‚Äôt use ‚Äòvery‚Äô

Why not use ‚Äòvery‚Äô? It‚Äôs not incorrect at all
column28: but using ‚Äòvery‚Äô actually prevents you from applying more descriptive vocabulary. For example
column30: why not say ‚Äòhuge‚Äô? Instead of saying the food is very good
column31: why not say that it is absolutely delicious? Just to get you started
column32:
here are some more phrases that you can use instead of saying ‚Äòvery‚Äô:
very good - terrific
column37:
microscopic
very old - ancient
very new - brand-new
very beautiful - gorgeous
very clean - spotless
